description:
Ypsolopha scabrella is a species of moth belonging to the family Ypsolophidae. It is a small-sized moth, typically measuring around 10-15 millimeters in wingspan.

The forewings of Ypsolopha scabrella are greyish-brown in color, often with darker markings or patterns. The hindwings are a paler, greyish shade. The moth's body and legs are also covered in greyish-brown scales.

The larvae, or caterpillars, of Ypsolopha scabrella feed on various plants, including hawthorn, blackthorn, and other members of the rose family (Rosaceae). The caterpillars can be found during the spring and early summer months.

Ypsolopha scabrella is widely distributed across Europe, with its range extending from the Iberian Peninsula to Scandinavia and eastern Europe. It is considered a common and widespread species within its geographical distribution.

This moth is often encountered in woodland habitats, hedgerows, and gardens where its host plants are present. The adults are typically active at night and can be attracted to light sources.
